issues.text: Whether Sumitra Devi got an absolute right of disposal in the share allotted to her on partition under Mitakshara law.

anchor.surface_text: It may be convenient to dispose of, first, the argument somewhat faintly advanced on behalf of the appellants that even prior to the enactment of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Sumitra Devi had an absolute right of disposal in the share allotted to her on partition in 1933-36 under Mitakshara law.

issues.text: Whether the share allotted to a mother on partition is stridhan or not, according to the Benares school.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the share allotted to a mother on partition is stridhan or not, according to the Benares school, was left open by their Lordships of the Privy Council in Bhugwandeen Doobey v. Myna Baee

anchor.surface_text: If a promise is made of such a gift for or at the time of the marriage, that promise may be fulfilled afterwards and it is not essential to make a gift at the time of the marriage but it may be made afterwards in fulfilment of the promise.

holdings.text: The finding of the High Court as to an ante-nuptial agreement for the gift of four houses at Asansol, worth about Rs. 20,000, is not vitiated by any error of fact or law. That finding must, therefore, be accepted as correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the finding of the High Court as to an ante-nuptial agreement for the gift of four houses at Asansol, worth about Rs. 20,000, is not vitiated by any error of fact or law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of Rai Saheb Jogendra Nath Roy tips the scale; no compelling reasons to differ from High Court despite Subordinate Judge's contrary view.

holdings.text: The appellants had failed to prove by satisfactory evidence that Mst. Sumitra Devi made a verbal gift of the four houses in question at the time of the marriage of her daughter Kamala Devi and that such a gift was accepted by Nand Lal on behalf of his minor daughter-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: we do not think that we shall be justified in going behind the finding of the Courts below that the appellants had failed to prove by satisfactory evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts; High Court confusion unfortunate but evidence unsatisfactory, including interested witnesses and discrepancies.

holdings.text: Under the Mitakshara law and also under the partition decree, Mst. Sumitra Devi did not have an absolute right or interest in the share allotted to her on partition.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that under the Mitakshara law and also under the partition decree, Mst. Sumitra Devi did not have an absolute right or interest in the share allotted to her on partition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partition decree limits to income without destroying corpus; follows Debi Mangal Prasad Singh v. Mahadeo Prasad Singh; Benares school not stridhan.

holdings.text: The share allotted to Mst. Sumitra Devi on partition stood on the same footing as property inherited by her from her husband. She had no absolute right of disposal of the property.

anchor.surface_text: Under the decision in Debi Mangal Prasad Singh v. Mahadeo Prasad Singh, the property allotted to Mst. Sumitra Devi on partition stood on the same footing as property inherited by her from her husband.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council in Debi Mangal holds no substantial difference between inheritance and partition share; not stridhan.

holdings.text: The concurrent finding of the Courts below that the gift of four houses at Asansol, of a value of about Rs. 19,000, was not disproportionate or unreasonable... is correct and must be accepted as such.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the very outset that the concurrent finding of the Courts below was that the gift of four houses at Asansol, of a value of about Rs. 19,000, was not disproportionate or unreasonable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Value ~Rs.19,000 reasonable portion of large estate even accounting for Rs.10,000 marriage expenses.

holdings.text: The alienation made by Mst. Sumitra Devi in favour of her daughter Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940, was valid and binding on the reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the alienation made by Mst. Sumitra Devi in favour of her daughter Kamala Devi on March 10, 1940, was valid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fulfils ante-nuptial promise as pious observance conferring spiritual benefit; reasonable portion; post-marriage fulfillment permitted under Hindu law precedents.

holdings.text: The learned Judges of the High Court were in error with regard to the scope and effect of s. 123 of the Transfer of Property Act. Section 123 does not deal with nor does it affect the power of a Hindu widow to make an alienation of a reasonable portion of her husbands estate in favour of the daughter as marriage dowry.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the learned Judges of the High Court were in error with regard to the scope and effect of s. 123 of the Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: TP Act governs form of gift but Hindu law governs widow's substantive power to alienate for dowry; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide this case on the rival contentions presented to us with regard to s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Gift valid under pre-existing Hindu law; s14 unnecessary to decide.

holdings.text: We allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on validity of gift under Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we allow the appeal and set aside the judgment and decree of the Courts below.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgments and decrees of the courts below set aside; gift deed held valid and binding on reversioners
